awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research - The Impact of Cybersecurity Policies on Employees' Efficiency and Performance Predictability
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is to conduct socio-cybersecurity research at a Historically Black University. The research problem being investigated is how cybersecurity procedures affect the efficiency of modern organizations. The specific research questions are: (1) What impact does the implementation of cybersecurity policies have on employees’ efficiency? and (2) What impact do cybersecurity protocols within an organization have on the predictability of employees’ responses to security vulnerabilities? This work is important because increasingly, cybersecurity is becoming an indelible part of workers’ lives. This modern workplace reality includes but goes beyond cybersecurity practitioners. Finally, the socio-cybersecurity project is important because of the relationships that will be fostered with local organizations within the university’s geographical research footprint.

The project team uses qualitative in-depth interviews to gather employees’ opinions about their efficiency and performance predictability. The interviews are built around a cybersecurity application that is a simulation of a workplace, which each respondent will navigate before the in-depth interviews. Multi-site quota sampling is used to recruit small groups of employees from about several companies across the Hampton Roads area in Virginia. Content analysis will be used to understand and disseminate data from the qualitative interviews. Students from organization courses in sociology, business, and cybersecurity will be recruited to pilot-test the interview schedule. This project will contribute to the social organizational theory literature by demonstrating how cybersecurity is both constrained and shaped by employees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Excellence in Research - The Impact of Cybersecurity Policies on Employees' Efficiency and Performance Predictability: A Sociology of Organization Analysis funded by the National Science Foundation (Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace division) realized several significant intellectual merits and broader impacts. The project team anticipated some of these results, as evident in the original proposal. However, others were positive and unanticipated outcomes. The following are some of the results achieved by the project team:

The Intellectual Merit

When this project was first conceptualized, the team was convinced there would be some value in building a framework for conducting socio-cybersecurity research at a Historically Black University, Norfolk State University (NSU). The intellectual merit of this project is based on the new sub-discipline of socio-cybersecurity. More specifically, the role of cybersecurity in social organizations was investigated in this project. Grounding the research in the McDonaldization concepts of efficiency and performance predictability was most appropriate, as it situated the research efforts in organizational sociology.

The research project was based on two distinct academic disciplines- Sociology and Computer Science. The team's composition allowed for the focus on completing deliverables through academic sub-groups. In terms of intellectual merit, creating the simulated SocioCyber app contributed to a growing niche area in data collection. The SocioCyber app aligns with simulation research used in academic and non-academic research as it captures functionality as the respondents respond to the scenarios presented through pop-up surveys.

A catalog of intellectual contributions resulted from this project from the analysis of the collected data over the four years. The two major research questions that drove the EiR empirical project investigated the impact of cybersecurity protocols and rules on employees' efficiency, and the impact of stringent cybersecurity protocols on performance predictability.

The analysis indicates that employees believe that security steps are necessary to prevent risks to organizations. This is because most employees do not want to be the cause of unintentional insider threats. Although employees recognize the necessity of cybersecurity protocols and rules in their organizations, they admitted that these requirements slowed them down, impacting efficiency.

A surprising finding and intellectual contribution from this project were developments around surveillance and the managerial gaze. The sentiment from the sample is that organizations are always watching their employees. This is a social contract between organizations and employees. Employees will allow the gaze because they do not want their organizations to be compromised. Employees did not believe they needed to be monitored in order to be productive. However, there was a consensus that unnecessary surveillance can erode trust in an organization.

The Broader Impact

As proposed, the SocioCybersecurity research project facilitated the establishment of a comprehensive research program in the Sociology department of an HBCU. The project established cutting-edge research at an HBCU. Several best practices resulted from the SocioCybersecurity research project. The first major deliverable was the face-to-face interviews that were conducted with fifty-six employees (37 from Hamptons Roads, Virginia, and 19 from Kingston, Jamaica) on the impact of cybersecurity policies on efficiency and performance predictability. The second part of the data collection was performed through a simulated survey app. The project team created a mock company website that required participants to perform several cybersecurity operations/scenarios. The SocioCyber app had pop-up questions that were prompted after scenarios.  

The project team consisted of three professors (two from sociology and one from computer science) and an evaluator from the School of Education. A contingent of very engaged research assistants were positively impacted by the project over the four-year period. This consisted of nineteen sociology students and nine computer science students. The team has helped propel interest in our research agenda.  

The project team also submitted a journal article and published a book chapter on mentoring research assistants on an interdisciplinary project at an HBCU. The major findings were that the student research appreciated role models who demonstrated technical phenomena. The Pis, who were the project mentors, deliberately grounded their interaction with the students in the references group typology for academic mentorship. Finally, bootstrapping was apparent in this project as the students were mentored by role models who looked like them.

Finally, the project initiatives helped to foster meaningful relationships with community stakeholders, allowing for a more positive interaction with our geographical research footprint. The debriefing session was most important to the participants, who were apprised of the project's achievements through the Workshop Luncheon for the team, participants, and interested parties.

Conclusion

In conclusion, tangible opportunities resulted from the Excellence in Research project. The project team successfully merged the disciplines of sociology and cybersecurity into a new research agenda. The innovative application of Ritzer's McDonaldization theory on a National Science Foundation award exemplifies a framework to measure employees' efficiency and performance predictability in the workplace. Overall, this demonstrates the importance of funding the SocioCybersecurity research initiatives emanating from our HBCUs.

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2024
Modified by: Carlene Turner
